## Design Your Research Journey

Research planning isn't about following a rigid checklist—it's about building **your** workflow. This phase of the research cycle brings together resources, ideas, and practices that help you make informed decisions before you begin.

**What you'll find here:** Options for exploring prior work, frameworks for documenting your plans, and tools that support transparent, reproducible research.

## Learn More: Foundational Concepts

Before diving into planning, these lectures provide essential context on research credibility and reproducibility:

- [Replicability Crisis](https://osf.io/mguqj/files/osfstorage) (1h) - Understanding threats to replicability
- [Credible Research](https://osf.io/rhtgn/files/osfstorage) (40 min) - Introduction to open research practices
- [Assessing Research Replicability](https://osf.io/dnym9/files/osfstorage) (1h) - Evaluating replication studies *(optional)*
- [Data Simulation in R](https://lmu-osc.github.io/Introduction-Simulations-in-R/) (2h) - Power analysis through simulation
- [Advanced Power Analyses](https://lmu-osc.github.io/Simulations-for-Advanced-Power-Analyses/) (6h) - Complex simulation designs *(optional)*
- [8-Step Checklist for Credible Research](https://www.psychologicalscience.org/observer/eight-easy-steps-for-improving-the-credibility-of-research) by Nosek et al. - Practical steps for improving research credibility
:::

## <i class="bi bi-clipboard-check"></i> Planning Framework Options

Different research contexts call for different planning approaches. Below are common frameworks researchers incorporate into their lab handbooks.

::: {.panel-tabset}

### Study Design

<details class="orc-details-panel">
<summary><i class="bi bi-lightbulb"></i> Preregistration</summary>

Many researchers document their hypotheses, methods, and analysis plans before data collection. Preregistration platforms allow time-stamping these decisions.

**Considerations for preregistration:**

- Research questions and hypotheses
- Sample size and stopping rules
- Variables and measures
- Statistical analysis plan
- Handling of missing data

::: {.callout-note appearance="simple" icon="mortarboard"}
## Learn More: Preregistration
[How to Prepare a Preregistration](https://lmu-osc.github.io/introduction-to-preregistration/) (2h) - Step-by-step guide to creating preregistrations using OSF and other platforms.
:::

**Helpful templates & guides:**

- [Pre-analysis checklist](https://blogs.worldbank.org/en/impactevaluations/a-pre-analysis-plan-checklist) by David McKenzie
- [Pre-analysis plan template](https://www.bitss.org/resource/alejandro-ganimians-pre-analysis-plan-template/) by Alejandro Ganimian
- [OSF Guide to Preregistration](https://help.osf.io/article/158-preregistration) - Step-by-step instructions

</details>

<details class="orc-details-panel">
<summary><i class="bi bi-file-earmark-check"></i> Registered Reports</summary>

Registered Reports are a publishing format where peer review occurs **before** data collection. If accepted, the journal commits to publishing regardless of results.

**Benefits:**

- Eliminates publication bias
- Separates hypothesis quality from results
- Provides in-principle acceptance before conducting research

**Resources:**

- [What are Registered Reports?](https://www.cos.io/initiatives/registered-reports) - COS overview and rationale
- [Journals accepting Registered Reports](https://www.cos.io/initiatives/registered-reports#702702cd-d4f3-4de9-bbb5-eb468e0dc804) - Growing list of participating journals
- [Author & Reviewer Guidelines](https://osf.io/pukzy/) - Templates and guidance for submissions

</details>

<details class="orc-details-panel">
<summary><i class="bi bi-calculator"></i> Power Analysis</summary>

Statistical power analysis helps determine appropriate sample sizes for detecting effects of interest.

**Common elements:**

- Expected effect size (from literature or pilot data)
- Desired statistical power (often 80-95%)
- Significance threshold (often α = 0.05)
- Analysis method (t-test, ANOVA, regression, etc.)

::: {.callout-note appearance="simple" icon="mortarboard"}
## Learn More: Power Analysis

- [Introduction to Data Simulation in R](https://lmu-osc.github.io/Introduction-Simulations-in-R/) (2h) - Create simulated datasets to test your analysis plans
- [Simulations for Advanced Power Analyses](https://lmu-osc.github.io/Simulations-for-Advanced-Power-Analyses/) (6h, can pick specific chapters) - Power analysis for complex statistical models including mixed models and factorial designs
- [Power Analysis Workshop](https://www.nicebread.de/workshop-on-power-analysis-by-simulation-in-r/) by Felix Schönbrodt - Comprehensive workshop materials on simulation-based power analysis
:::

::: {.callout-tip}

Data Management Plans (DMPs) outline how research data will be handled throughout and after a project.

:::

::: {.callout-tip}

### Ethics & Compliance

Depending on the research type, various ethical and compliance considerations may apply.

**Common approvals and frameworks:**

- Institutional review board (IRB) or ethics committee approval
- Informed consent procedures
- Data protection regulations (e.g., GDPR, HIPAA)
- Animal welfare protocols (where applicable)
- Biosafety and environmental safety reviews

**Consent form templates for open data sharing:**

- [German templates](https://osf.io/mgwk8/wiki/Consent%20form%20templates%20for%20open%20data/) - Dyadic and non-dyadic experiments (OSC collection)
- [English templates](https://osf.io/adkj4/) - COS Reproducible Research collection

::: {.callout-note}
## Documentation
Many labs maintain a centralized log of all ethics approvals, consent forms, and compliance certifications for easy reference.
:::

::: {.callout-tip}
## Our Recommendation: LMU Ethics & Compliance

**LMU Ethics Committee** reviews all research involving human participants.

- **Website**: [Ethics Committee Information](https://www.med.lmu.de/de/fakultaet/wer-wir-sind/gremien-kommissionen/ethikkommission/)
- **Timeline**: ~4 weeks for initial review, ~1 week for revisions, ~3 weeks for final approval
- **Note**: Only the Principal Investigator (PI) can submit ethics applications

**LMU Guidelines for Good Scientific Practice** (2023) establish standards for all research at LMU:

- Reproducible methods must be used
- Complete documentation to enable replication
- Data, materials, and software must follow FAIR principles
- Research outputs preserved for 10 years
- [German regulation (legally binding)](https://www.lmu.de/de/die-lmu/struktur/zentrale-universitaetsverwaltung/dez-vi-lehre-und-studium/ref-vi-2-stabsstelle-lehrqualitaet-und-evaluation/gute-wissenschaftliche-praxis/)
:::

:::

## <i class="bi bi-clipboard2-check"></i> Consideration: Sharing Your Plan

Some research teams find it helpful to present their study plans to colleagues before beginning data collection.

::: {.orc-gradient-box}

### Why some teams share their plans:

- **Feedback opportunity**: Colleagues may identify potential issues or suggest improvements
- **Methodological review**: Domain experts can validate design choices
- **Resource awareness**: Others may know of relevant tools or data
- **Collaborative refinement**: Discussion often strengthens the research approach

### Elements researchers typically include when presenting:

<div class="orc-grid-2col">

<div>
- Research questions/hypotheses
- Study design overview
- Sample size justification
- Measurement approach
</div>

<div>
- Analysis strategy
- Data management approach
- Timeline and milestones
- Potential limitations
</div>

</div>

:::
